It has often been hypothesized that violence seems to rise in densely populated areas. In his book, Malcolm Gladwell points out the observation that has been made to support this hypothesis: when you pack too many species, or people, in one area or small space, there is a rising probability of them becoming aggressive with one another. Walking down any street in a city, you have a bigger chance of experiencing a violent act than in one that doesn’t, even though it is possible to see it anywhere in the world, including rural places.
;

If someone feels as if they are threatened, they could also fight against someone using violent force in retaliation. Does this kind of attitude really make any positive change? Or does violence - no matter from what side it is coming - perpetuate violence?

;The question is, how can ethics assuredly affect violence -- even in the middle of an already violent society? If you’re unsure of what ethics is, you can equate it to your intuition. You can see in the way a person lives if they have good morals or otherwise. You need to stand with what you believe in when it applies to your moral beliefs or you won’t be able to make decisive choices that could determine your life. If their ethical code is strong, it is likely that this person will have an idea of how to handle challenging situations as they occur. They are more likely to be consistent and feel a sense of surety about their decision.
;
;Violence is an issue that many people have a hard time swallowing. Injuring someone or stealing from someone is something most of us wouldn’t even conceive. If you have a good solid ethical background, the thought of hurting someone, letting alone killing them, would never even cross our minds. How is this achievable? Were we made to avoid violence at all costs? Will we see positive effects on the way we feel about the subject of violence if we build better ethics? If people have been raised with an objective view of violence, is there a way to teach them something different? If we all strive towards building these block for better ethics, we will more than likely see a difference.
